subsubsection.title: Differentiability & Non-Differentiability

definition.title: Differentiability
definition.p: A function f is differentiable at a if f'(a) exists. It is differentiable on an open interval (a,b) if it is differentiable at every number in the interval.

assemblage.title: A Note
assemblage.p:
Here is the formal definition of differentiability: a function f(x) is differentiable at a if
\lim_{h\to 0^-} \dfrac{f(x+h)-f(x)}{h} = \lim_{h\to 0^+} \dfrac{f(x+h)-f(x)}{h}

assemblage.title: Differentiability vs. Continuity
assemblage.p: If a function f is differentiable, then it is continuous; the reverse is not true.

subsubsection.p:
There are several characteristics which indicate that a graph is not differentiable at a point:
A sharp corner
A discontinuity
A vertical tangent line

subsubsection.title: Other Notations
subsubsection.p:
When we want to evaluate a derivative, we often use a vertical bar to communicate that we are evaluating. If f(x) = x^2, then f'(x) = 2x, and f'(1) = 2; we could also notate this by writing
\dfrac{dy}{dx}\bigg\rvert_{x = 1} = 2

subsubsection.title: Higher Derivatives
subsubsection.p: In physics, higher-order derivatives are very important. If s(t) is a position function, then the first derivative s'(t) is called the velocity, often written as v(t). The second derivative of position (so, the first derivative of velocity) is called acceleration, often written as a(t). The third derivative also has a special name, called the jerk, j(t).
